sub_topic: Calculating the molar mass of inorganic compounds
message_1: What is the molar mass of magnesium chloride (MgCl2)?
message_2:
To find the molar mass of magnesium chloride (MgCl2), we need to add the molar masses of magnesium (Mg) and two chlorine (Cl) atoms.

The molar mass of magnesium (Mg) is approximately 24.305 g/mol.
The molar mass of chlorine (Cl) is approximately 35.453 g/mol.

Since there are two chlorine atoms in MgCl2, we need to multiply the molar mass of chlorine by 2:

2 * 35.453 g/mol = 70.906 g/mol

Now, add the molar mass of magnesium to the total molar mass of the two chlorine atoms:

24.305 g/mol (Mg) + 70.906 g/mol (2 Cl) = 95.211 g/mol

The molar mass of magnesium chloride (MgCl2) is approximately 95.211 g/mol.
